statements.statement: Laws concerning abortion should prioritize protecting unborn life while also recognizing rare and serious circumstances where a mother’s life or health is at risk. I believe each state should have the right to set its own policies, grounded in moral and religious values, scientific understanding of fetal development, and respect for families and communities.

statements.statement: Las leyes sobre el aborto deben guiarse, ante todo, por el valor sagrado de la vida que Dios nos da, desde la concepción hasta la muerte natural. Como conservador y cristiano protestante, creo que el gobierno tiene la responsabilidad de proteger a los más vulnerables, incluyendo a los niños por nacer, salvo en raros casos donde la vida de la madre esté en grave peligro. También pienso que la sociedad debe ofrecer más apoyo moral, económico y comunitario a las mujeres embarazadas para que no vean el aborto como su única opción.

statements.statement: Laws concerning abortion should prioritize women’s health, safety, and autonomy, guided by medical evidence rather than political or religious agendas. As a nurse and a mother, I believe decisions about pregnancy are deeply personal and should be made by a woman in consultation with her healthcare provider, not the government. At the same time, I support policies that expand access to contraception, comprehensive sex education, and prenatal care so fewer women face crisis pregnancies in the first place.

statements.statement: Laws concerning abortion should prioritize a woman’s right to make decisions about her own body, guided by medical science and respect for individual circumstances rather than religious doctrine or political ideology. As a Catholic, I personally value life, but I don’t think my religious beliefs should control what others are allowed to do, especially in complex situations like health risks or cases of rape. The government should protect access to safe, legal abortion while also supporting comprehensive sex education, contraception, and social services so fewer people are forced into impossible choices.

statements.statement: Laws concerning abortion should be guided by the belief that life begins at conception and deserves strong legal protection, except in rare cases like when the mother’s life is in serious danger. From my years in law enforcement, I’ve seen how vulnerable lives can be, and I believe the law has a duty to defend those who cannot defend themselves. While I respect that people face difficult situations, I think our laws should lean toward preserving life and encouraging responsibility, not making abortion a routine option.

statements.statement: Laws concerning abortion should prioritize a woman’s right to make decisions about her own body, guided by medical evidence and respect for individual circumstances, not by religious doctrine or partisan politics. As a liberal Catholic, I personally value life deeply, but I don’t think my faith should be imposed through law on people with different beliefs or situations. The government’s role should be to ensure safe, accessible reproductive healthcare, comprehensive sex education, and social support so that people have real choices rather than forced outcomes.

statements.statement: As a conservative Protestant and a mother who grew up with strong traditional values, I believe our laws on abortion should be guided first by the sanctity of human life and the protection of the unborn. Society should put more effort into supporting women with real alternatives—like adoption and better community support—so that ending a pregnancy is not seen as the easiest or only option.

statements.statement: I think laws about abortion should try to protect unborn life as much as possible, because I was raised Catholic and taught that every life is important. At the same time, they should also make sure the mother is safe and supported, especially in really serious situations like danger to her life or cases of rape. I don’t think it should be treated like just another medical choice, but something very serious that people, families, and doctors think deeply about.
